poem:
### A Pall of Words

In morning's delicate light,  
newspaper ink unfurls its shadows,  
an echo of the past replayed,  
where the dove and hawk entwine.  
Appalled, sickened—words  
are brittle leaves beneath heavy boots,  
and here, hope is a silent sigh,  
lost in the smoke and cries—  
cinders of a dream deferred.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Lammy ‘sickened’ by Israel’s targeting of starving Palestinians and threatens fresh sanctions The UK foreign secretary has said he is “appalled, sickened” by the “grotesque” targeting of starving Palestinians seeking food by the Israeli military, saying there would be further sanctions if the war did not end soon. Israel on Monday launched air raids and a ground operation in Gaza, targeting Deir al-Balah, the main hub for humanitarian efforts. Military action over the weekend resulted". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
